Paragraph: We draw two main conclusions from these mixed results. First, while the initial shock may have been similar across sectors, recovery may depend on the context or external conditions. In our case, the faster recovery of manufacturing may be related to the overall booming in the manufacturing sector experienced in the United States during the post-war period. Second, even after a recovery in prices—the value of farms and of livestock— the response to the shock may cause changes in the institutions or organization of economic activity that persist even longer. In the case of post- bellum Georgia, North Carolina, and South Carolina, that new institution was sharecropping and tenant farming. In particular, we document that the areas aﬀected by the shock saw a shift in the 6While this credit mechanism does not require a direct negative eﬀect of Sherman’s march on banks, it would be reinforced by one. As we discuss later in the paper, we suspect that Sherman’s march did have a negative eﬀect on the banking sector. However, we consider this to be part of the overall treatment. We test the credit mechanism using only potential treatment intensity, based on preexisting bank or credit access rather than the post-treatment declines. However, we show results are similar when using the change in banks as treatment
Context: We draw two main conclusions from these mixed results. First, while the initial shock may have been similar across sectors, recovery may depend on the context or external conditions.
Sentence: In our case, the faster recovery of manufacturing may be related to the overall booming in the manufacturing sector experienced in the United States during the post-war period.

Paragraph: With this paper, we contribute to three related literatures. The ﬁrst examines the eﬀects of capital and infrastructure destruction on economic local activity.7Ikle (1952) studied this in the context of the Allied bombing of German cities during World War II and found that bombed cities rebuilt fairly quickly after the war. Davis and Weinstein (2002) similarly showed rapid postwar reconstruction of Japanese cities destroyed during WWII. Miguel and Roland (2011) found that Vietnamese districts severely damaged by American bombing in the late 1960s and early 1970s also rebuilt shortly after ﬁghting ceased. We contribute to the literature in several ways. We are the ﬁrst among these papers to examine how capital destruction aﬀects business development across diﬀerent sectors.8Many of the previous papers focus on population and other general demographic variables, which may fail to capture important economic dimensions of the costs of capital destruc- tion. Consistent with this hypothesis, our paper ﬁnds essentially no eﬀect on population, but very large negative eﬀects in both the agricultural and manufacturing sector after the crisis. Further, our analysis on the longer-run eﬀects of the shock also provides two novel insights. First, we highlight the importance of the economic context to assess the actual eﬀect of a shock. As we show, the reversal was quicker in manufacturing, an economic area that—unlike postbellum agriculture—was experiencing high growth overall. Second, we discuss the importance of understanding how capital shockscanchangethewayeconomicactivityisorganized. Asweshowinthepaper, thisinstitutional shift may persist over the long-run and, consistent with the literature on the role of institutions on growth (Dell 2010; Acemoglu, Johnson, and Robinson 2001), have long-run eﬀects on growth and 7In examining the eﬀects of a large, destructive capital shock, this paper is also relevant to the literature on the eﬀectiveness of post-shock reconstruction plans. Recent examples in this area include the impact of the Marshall Plan in Italy after WWII (Bianchi and Giorcelli 2018; Giorcelli 2018) and post-Katrina rebuilding plans (e.g. Gregory 2017)
Sentence: With this paper, we contribute to three related literatures.

Paragraph: Even foreign observers remarked on the novelty of war to the region: writing a travelogue through the postbellum South, an English Member of Parliament recalled that Sherman marched “through States which had never had the war brought home to them, or even seen the blue uniform of their Yankee foes”. Sherman’s destruction extended even to paperwork: in a study of bankruptcy cases in postbellum South Carolina, Thompson (2004) describes several claimants blaming Sherman for destroying their records and complicating the unwinding of debt obligations
Context: Even foreign observers remarked on the novelty of war to the region: writing a travelogue through the postbellum South, an English Member of Parliament recalled that Sherman marched “through States which had never had the war brought home to them, or even seen the blue uniform of their Yankee foes”.
Sentence: Sherman’s destruction extended even to paperwork: in a study of bankruptcy cases in postbellum South Carolina, Thompson (2004) describes several claimants blaming Sherman for destroying their records and complicating the unwinding of debt obligations

Paragraph: Overall, this analysis shows that the capital destruction caused by Sherman’s march substantially aﬀected the local agricultural economy, with the eﬀects still visible in 1870, six years later.
Sentence: Overall, this analysis shows that the capital destruction caused by Sherman’s march substantially aﬀected the local agricultural economy, with the eﬀects still visible in 1870, six years later.

Paragraph: Conﬂict and other disasters have caused destruction and economic mayhem throughout human history, but the study of their eﬀects on growth remains limited. Fur- thermore, little work has examined the economic factors that may aﬀect the recovery process, speciﬁcally the role of credit markets. In a standard neoclassical growth model, a temporary shock to capital should be followed by rapid growth, bringing the economy back to the original steady state quickly, with no consequences in the medium run. Evidence in this direction has been pre- sented by several papers, all examining the eﬀects of wartime destruction in the twentieth century. In this paper, we study the long- and medium-run eﬀects of capital destruction on local economies using General William Sherman’s 1864-65 military march during the American Civil War as a shock to local capital. We estimate that capital destruction had large negative eﬀects on both the agricultural and manufacturing sectors, with some agricultural eﬀects persisting until 1920 because of changes to agricultural institutions
Sentence: Conﬂict and other disasters have caused destruction and economic mayhem throughout human history, but the study of their eﬀects on growth remains limited.

Paragraph: The Census of Agriculture deﬁnes improved acres of farmland as land in farms cleared for tillage, grazing, grass, or lying fallow; unimproved areas are deﬁned as uncultivated land connected to farms, including both fertile and waste acres. This measure is consistently employed across the 1850–1920 US Censuses of Agriculture.
Context: The Census of Agriculture deﬁnes improved acres of farmland as land in farms cleared for tillage, grazing, grass, or lying fallow; unimproved areas are deﬁned as uncultivated land connected to farms, including both fertile and waste acres.
Sentence: This measure is consistently employed across the 1850–1920 US Censuses of Agriculture.

Paragraph: The breadth of James Crawford’s work as an academic and practitioner of international law is astonishing: from boundary delimitation, to foundational sources questions, to the complexities of International Centre for Settlement of Investment Disputes (ICSID) annulment, little seemed beyond his grasp or his interest. From the 1990s onwards, State responsibility became a focus of his work. As the International Law Commission’s (ILC or Commission) fifth Special Rapporteur on the topic, employing (as Bruno Simma recently noted) an admirable combination of ‘intellectual courage and resolve’,  James Crawford guided the Commission through a swift second reading of the Articles on Responsibility of States for Internationally Wrongful Acts (Articles or ILC Articles). The eventual text, adopted in 2001 and annexed to United Nations (UN) General Assembly resolution 56/83, while reflecting a collective ILC effort, bears his imprint.
Sentence: The breadth of James Crawford’s work as an academic and practitioner of international law is astonishing: from boundary delimitation, to foundational sources questions, to the complexities of International Centre for Settlement of Investment Disputes (ICSID) annulment, little seemed beyond his grasp or his interest.

Paragraph: Second, the ILC has also provided international law with a way of thinking about responsibility, with concepts and a terminology: with a code in a lexical sense. This terminology can be forbidding, but it has come to stick. Today’s students and practitioners of international law effortlessly use many of the ILC’s more burdensome terms, such as ‘State other than the injured State’ and ‘circumstances precluding wrongfulness’ (where ‘defences’ might have done). Conversely, ageing teachers feel the need to explain what they mean by ‘reprisals’ (a term branded as regressive by the ILC, and replaced by the term ‘countermeasure’). But beyond the terminology, the ILC’s encoding has left us with a mindset for thinking about responsibility which is shaped by three ‘basal presumptions’: responsibility is today generally understood to be an objective concept not necessarily dependent on fault or damage; it is a general notion applying to custom and treaty breaches alike; and, most significantly, it is a system of secondary rules that formulates ‘general conditions … for the State to be considered responsible for wrongful actions or omissions, and the legal consequences which flow therefrom’. The Articles’ distinction between three substantive parts – addressing, respectively, the origin, content and implementation of responsibility – and its further subdivision between the conditions for responsibility and the circumstances precluding wrongfulness, structures the way we teach the topic, and in its charming simplicity is likely to have made this allegedly intractable topic accessible.
Context: Second, the ILC has also provided international law with a way of thinking about responsibility, with concepts and a terminology: with a code in a lexical sense. This terminology can be forbidding, but it has come to stick.
Sentence: Today’s students and practitioners of international law effortlessly use many of the ILC’s more burdensome terms, such as ‘State other than the injured State’ and ‘circumstances precluding wrongfulness’ (where ‘defences’ might have done).

Paragraph: There is much to be said for this approach to the Articles. As Section 4 showed, the Articles have been well received in many fields of international law. Refinements and clarifications are necessary, to be sure, but this is a normal part of the adaptation of legal rules to the changing character of State interactions, and to the emergence of new challenges and threats. The Articles, grounded as they are in customary law, are amenable to such refinement and adaptation through State practice. Most importantly, however, the system of responsibility codified in the Articles works. A codification conference could alter the ‘delicate balance’ of this system and create instability and uncertainty were the treaty adopted not to be ratified by States.
Context: There is much to be said for this approach to the Articles. As Section 4 showed, the Articles have been well received in many fields of international law. Refinements and clarifications are necessary, to be sure, but this is a normal part of the adaptation of legal rules to the changing character of State interactions, and to the emergence of new challenges and threats.
Sentence: The Articles, grounded as they are in customary law, are amenable to such refinement and adaptation through State practice.

Paragraph: Third, in the field of human rights, according to the UN Secretariat’s technical report listing international decisions that cite the Articles, by 2017 the Articles had been referred to in 65 decisions by the regional human rights courts and the Human Rights Committee combined. While this number may appear small, especially if contrasted with investment arbitration, it rebuts Malcolm Evans’s prediction that ‘the international principles of State responsibility [are] irrelevant’ to the operation of human rights treaties. Indeed, Helen Duffy has discerned an increasing engagement of human rights courts and tribunals, as well as other actors involved in human rights monitoring, with the Articles, and noted that this increased engagement is both quantitative and qualitative.
Sentence: Third, in the field of human rights, according to the UN Secretariat’s technical report listing international decisions that cite the Articles, by 2017 the Articles had been referred to in 65 decisions by the regional human rights courts and the Human Rights Committee combined.

Paragraph: Unsurprisingly, James Crawford was often asked to comment on the ILC Articles. From early on in his work as a Special Rapporteur, he recognised their special status: in a 1999 symposium of the European Journal of International Law devoted to the process of the second reading, notwithstanding significant reservations about certain aspects, he considered the first-reading text of 1996 to ‘ha[ve] become part of the mental landscape of international lawyers’. One and a half decades later, in State Responsibility: The General Part, this was condensed into the confident, if succinct, claim that ‘[t]he ILC Articles represent the modern framework of state responsibility’. In our view, the status of the ILC Articles is best captured in a third statement, also offered with the benefit of hindsight: ‘The Articles have encoded the way in which we think about [State] responsibility’. ‘Encoding’ is indeed what the ILC Articles have done to a framework of legal rules that (like those pertaining to jurisdiction) for a long time appeared amorphous and elusive. They have done so in the two senses of the word ‘code’.
Context: Unsurprisingly, James Crawford was often asked to comment on the ILC Articles. From early on in his work as a Special Rapporteur, he recognised their special status: in a 1999 symposium of the European Journal of International Law devoted to the process of the second reading, notwithstanding significant reservations about certain aspects, he considered the first-reading text of 1996 to ‘ha[ve] become part of the mental landscape of international lawyers’. One and a half decades later, in State Responsibility: The General Part, this was condensed into the confident, if succinct, claim that ‘[t]he ILC Articles represent the modern framework of state responsibility’.
Sentence: In our view, the status of the ILC Articles is best captured in a third statement, also offered with the benefit of hindsight: ‘The Articles have encoded the way in which we think about [State] responsibility’.

Paragraph: Consolidation and refinement are part of the ongoing engagementwith the ILCArticles, which for two decades have been tested in practice. Overall, it seems clear that the Articles have stood the test of time. In a formally non-binding text, the Commission has distilled a framework that iswidely taken to reflect customary international law (a successful exercise in what has been referred to as ‘codification light’). In this sense, as suggested by James Crawford, the legal form of the Articles seems not to have mattered all that much.
Context: Consolidation and refinement are part of the ongoing engagementwith the ILCArticles, which for two decades have been tested in practice.
Sentence: Overall, it seems clear that the Articles have stood the test of time.

Paragraph: Supporters of the so-called ‘classical theory’ also viewed this generalisation with some restraint and scepticism (in particular, to the extent that it excluded from its ambit the elements of fault and damage). Informed by the laws of obligations and civil codes of many civil law countries, the classical theory considered responsibility to require three basic elements: damage, faulty conduct, and a causal link between the two. Some scholars, like Eduardo Jiménez de Aréchaga and Hubert Thierry, eschewed the element of fault but continued to require damage as a necessary element of responsibility (that is, in the ILC’s terminology, as a matter of secondary rules). In the German context, Ingo von Münch’s influential 1963 study Das Völkerrechtliche Delikt pointed in the same direction (insisting on damage, but not necessarily on fault), and began a decade-long discussion about results-based and fault-based responsibility (Erfolgshaftung und Schuldhaftung) that did not necessarily track the ILC’s discussions. As a variation on these approaches, Brigitte Stern’s influential work overcame strictures of the classical approach, but did so ‘from within’, namely by relying on expansive notions of ‘damage/injury’.
Context: Supporters of the so-called ‘classical theory’ also viewed this generalisation with some restraint and scepticism (in particular, to the extent that it excluded from its ambit the elements of fault and damage). Informed by the laws of obligations and civil codes of many civil law countries, the classical theory considered responsibility to require three basic elements: damage, faulty conduct, and a causal link between the two.
Sentence: Some scholars, like Eduardo Jiménez de Aréchaga and Hubert Thierry, eschewed the element of fault but continued to require damage as a necessary element of responsibility (that is, in the ILC’s terminology, as a matter of secondary rules).

Paragraph: It would be wrong (and out of character) to read this as the view of an architect worried that ‘his project’ might be dismantled or disfigured. Rather, these statements reflect a quality that characterised James Crawford as a scholar and practitioner of international law: a certain wariness for overly principled arguments (such as, that a topic as weighty as responsibility would simply have to be ‘treatified’ because treaties were the natural or inherently superior outcome of ILC processes or were a natural and inherently superior source as compared with customary law).
Sentence: It would be wrong (and out of character) to read this as the view of an architect worried that ‘his project’ might be dismantled or disfigured.

Paragraph: For many, the lesson learned from The Hague Codification Conference’s failure was that codification of responsibility by focusing on injury to foreigners was unproductive.
Sentence: For many, the lesson learned from The Hague Codification Conference’s failure was that codification of responsibility by focusing on injury to foreigners was unproductive.

Paragraph: The ILC Articles are among the discipline’s best-known texts, being one of the most consulted and cited. It is difficult to ‘do’ international law, or credibly pretend to do so, without at least a general knowledge of the ILC Articles. Indeed, as Section 4 will show, the ILC Articles are essential in the day-to-day working of many fields of international law. This owes a lot to their subject matter: regulating responsibility for the breach of legal rules is a central function of legal systems and hugely relevant in the practical application of the law; international law is no exception. But there is more to the Articles than subject-matter relevance. Whereas international law’s approach to other central, practically relevant matters (such as jurisdiction or statehood) remains diffuse and elusive, the framework of the ‘law of State responsibility’ can be easily located in a text of 59 provisions, readily available online and in any decent statute book. At no more than 14 pages of text in the ILC’s Yearbook, this framework is quite easily digestible, at least by international legal standards.
Context: It is difficult to ‘do’ international law, or credibly pretend to do so, without at least a general knowledge of the ILC Articles. Indeed, as Section 4 will show, the ILC Articles are essential in the day-to-day working of many fields of international law. This owes a lot to their subject matter: regulating responsibility for the breach of legal rules is a central function of legal systems and hugely relevant in the practical application of the law; international law is no exception.
Sentence: But there is more to the Articles than subject-matter relevance.

Paragraph: It is difficult now to fully grasp the opposition to the ILC’s approach, or indeed the heated nature of debates about fault and damage as general conditions of responsibility. Looked at with the benefit of hindsight, the ILC’s system of responsibility did not so much supplant as subsume these other approaches, thus ensuring its success over them. Profitably generalised, the law of responsibility as encoded by the ILC has shed much of its conceptual baggage. Lightened and truly general, the regime is both flexible (so that it can accommodate requirements of fault and damage where the primary rules require these) and residual (so that it can accommodate special responsibility rules in particular fields of international law). The system’s impact on actual outcomes may not always run very deep: staying clear of the primary rules and outsourcing many debates to those primary rules, the ILC’s Articles for the most part supply categories and structures. To return to our initial Crawford quote, the Articles ‘encoded … the way in which we think about responsibility’, rather than necessarily mandating a particular outcome in each and every case. But this modesty is part of their success. Despite the growing specialisation of responsibility within certain fields of international law, the Articles have shown, in Katja Creutz’s terms, ‘tenacity’: sometimes in the foreground and sometimes in the background, they have remained at the centre of the law of responsibility.
Context: The system’s impact on actual outcomes may not always run very deep: staying clear of the primary rules and outsourcing many debates to those primary rules, the ILC’s Articles for the most part supply categories and structures. To return to our initial Crawford quote, the Articles ‘encoded … the way in which we think about responsibility’, rather than necessarily mandating a particular outcome in each and every case. But this modesty is part of their success.
Sentence: Despite the growing specialisation of responsibility within certain fields of international law, the Articles have shown, in Katja Creutz’s terms, ‘tenacity’: sometimes in the foreground and sometimes in the background, they have remained at the centre of the law of responsibility.

Paragraph: As is clear from the preceding section, the ILC’s encoding project has mainly been an exercise in condensing and extracting, most obviously aided by the decision to focus on secondary rules. Commenting shortly after the adoption of the text, James Crawford (perhaps somewhat cautiously) described this ‘move to a set of articles dealing solely with secondary obligations’ as ‘a step in the direction of profitable generalization’.39 As he noted later, ‘international law has to address a wide range of needs’ through ‘a few basic tools and techniques’. In generalising the system of responsibility, the ILC ensured that with a few basic tools it would indeed be possible to address all of the different ways in which States (regrettably) violate the wide variety of obligations that they have towards other subjects of international law. This was indeed profitable: it is because of their generality that the ILC Articles rather quickly supplanted other ways of thinking about responsibility in international law.
Context: As is clear from the preceding section, the ILC’s encoding project has mainly been an exercise in condensing and extracting, most obviously aided by the decision to focus on secondary rules. Commenting shortly after the adoption of the text, James Crawford (perhaps somewhat cautiously) described this ‘move to a set of articles dealing solely with secondary obligations’ as ‘a step in the direction of profitable generalization’.39 As he noted later, ‘international law has to address a wide range of needs’ through ‘a few basic tools and techniques’. In generalising the system of responsibility, the ILC ensured that with a few basic tools it would indeed be possible to address all of the different ways in which States (regrettably) violate the wide variety of obligations that they have towards other subjects of international law.
Sentence: This was indeed profitable: it is because of their generality that the ILC Articles rather quickly supplanted other ways of thinking about responsibility in international law.

Paragraph: To conclude on this first point, it seems to us that, while the ILC did not invent the law of State responsibility, its approach is now the only meaningful path to understanding it. Synthesising case law, State practice, and scholarly commentary, the ILC came up with the blueprint: it moulded the law, and it notably distilled from the mass of material several general categories through which we now approach responsibility (internationally wrongful acts, attribution, aid and assistance, and so on). That the ILC succeeded in ‘encoding’ this field of law, which to Sir Gerald Fitzmaurice had seemed to be one of the ‘most traditional and yet most elusive, unsettled, and intractable problem[s]’ of international law, is no mean feat. The fact that we hardly notice it today only reflects the success of the encoding exercise.
Sentence: To conclude on this first point, it seems to us that, while the ILC did not invent the law of State responsibility, its approach is now the only meaningful path to understanding it.

Paragraph: First, by offering a systematisation of the rules in this field, the ILC has left international lawyers with a code in a legal sense. That is, a coherent system of rules regulating a particular area of the law. This was not an easy task. An earlier attempt at an institutional codification of aspects of the law of responsibility, the League of Nations’ 1930 Codification Conference at The Hague, had ended in failure. On that occasion, after preparatory work spanning roughly four years, and a conference lasting four weeks, the Third Committee appointed to consider ‘Responsibility of States for Damage caused in their Territory to the Person or Property of Foreigners’, with representatives from 42 States, only managed to adopt 10 articles before ‘confessing its inability to arrive at a convention’.
Context: First, by offering a systematisation of the rules in this field, the ILC has left international lawyers with a code in a legal sense. That is, a coherent system of rules regulating a particular area of the law.
Sentence: This was not an easy task.

Paragraph: First, Kubo Mačák has noted that the Articles have had ‘significant impact on the application and interpretation’ of international humanitarian law. Specifically, in his view, the Articles have become an indispensable resource in assessing State responsibility for violations of international humanitarian law. The 2020 updated commentaries of the International Committee of the Red Cross on the 1949 Geneva Conventions indicate that the Articles are a key element of the legal framework within which the Conventions must be interpreted and applied.
Context: First, Kubo Mačák has noted that the Articles have had ‘significant impact on the application and interpretation’ of international humanitarian law.
Sentence: Specifically, in his view, the Articles have become an indispensable resource in assessing State responsibility for violations of international humanitarian law.

Paragraph: These fundamental obstacles can remain theoretical. We saw, in contrast, how Leiris concretely encounters an obstacle to his ideal of self-understanding. A parallel point, where analysis, the attempt to “penetrate” the psyche’s depth, runs against something resistant to introspection or interpretation, appears rather early in the history of psychoanalysis. This point receives only a marginal place in Freud’s The Interpretation of Dreams, a footnote, but it is certainly the most famous footnote in the history of psychoanalysis.
Context: These fundamental obstacles can remain theoretical.
Sentence: We saw, in contrast, how Leiris concretely encounters an obstacle to his ideal of self-understanding.

Paragraph: autobiography are in conflict, being two parallel routes to self-understanding.The chapter begins by naming a few discoveries the author made since the publication of the first volume. One of them troubles Leiris: Visiting his sister, he leafs through a collection of old periodicals and comes across a picture of the singer Lucy Arbell in the role of Persephone, wearing large disc-shaped metal ornaments over her ears (Scraps 13). In the first volume, Scratches, Leiris devoted an entire chapter to the figure of Persephone, where various associations with round, spiral, and curved objects, as well as elements concerning sound and hearing, were evoked in an attempt to understand what Persephone symbolized for him. Having run into the old picture by accident, Leiris suddenly understands that the link he made between Persephone, spiral objects and hearing came from this disc-shaped metal ornament in a picture that he saw as a child and then remained engraved in his memory. The central link influencing his previous thoughts and associations was completely hidden to him, only discovered by sheer chance.
Context: autobiography are in conflict, being two parallel routes to self-understanding.The chapter begins by naming a few discoveries the author made since the publication of the first volume.
Sentence: One of them troubles Leiris: Visiting his sister, he leafs through a collection of old periodicals and comes across a picture of the singer Lucy Arbell in the role of Persephone, wearing large disc-shaped metal ornaments over her ears (Scraps 13).

Paragraph: As in a successful psychoanalysis, the autobiography turns from a search for certainty to an acknowledgement of complexity. Leiris’s wish for a complete, transparent self-understanding failed, to be sure, but the search for it yielded a fascinating text and a lifetime odyssey of self-enquiry. Broadly then, one witnesses in Leiris’s work a transition from the search for a treasure box of meaning to a meandering among details and trivialities, among scraps or fourbis. As Barberger underscores, the belief in the lacuna, the origin to be found, the lost object, disperses, becoming minute echoes. Leiris, we have seen, is eager to find an oasis, to reach complete self-understanding, to touch the truth, but he is lost in a desert of triviality.
Sentence: As in a successful psychoanalysis, the autobiography turns from a search for certainty to an acknowledgement of complexity.

Paragraph: How can such a lacuna be filled? How can one uncover what one does not know? Looking closely at the nature of Leiris’s search, we can see how profoundly close it is to psychoanalysis. He places in brackets the question of what death really is—or the real presence of death—and turns to examining the way death functions or resonates in his psychic world. In this course of action, the emphasis shifts from reality to its resonance within us, turning our gaze from the world to the way it is absorbed and metabolized inside, to the intricate web of subjective meanings that our mind has weaved around it. This is in fact the psychoanalytic approach. Thus, external, unfathomable death—a hole in his understanding of the world—is to be replaced by memories, thoughts, associations, and images of death. These will fill the next several dozen pages of “Mors”—an abundance of death-related memories, associations, anecdotes, and personal interpretations of the presence of death in his life.
Context: How can such a lacuna be filled?
Sentence: How can one uncover what one does not know?

Paragraph: The lacuna then, is death.6 Death is not a lacuna accidental to autobiography, but one of principle. Leiris’s attempt to find out when he became aware of his death seems to be a displacement of a more significant difficulty, namely, his death pure and simple.
Context: The lacuna then, is death.6 Death is not a lacuna accidental to autobiography, but one of principle.
Sentence: Leiris’s attempt to find out when he became aware of his death seems to be a displacement of a more significant difficulty, namely, his death pure and simple.

Paragraph: This evasive move to the one lacuna, to the search for one crucial moment, seems to be soothing even in its affirmation that something will remain unknown. After all, the possibility Leiris has faced at the beginning of the chapter, namely that his entire psyche is to a large extent unknown to him and that his text, his self-construction as it were, is something foreign to him, is extremely troubling. Surely, looking for one central event that escapes him while saving the more general structure of the intelligibility of his text and the transparency of the self, is a much better choice.
Context: This evasive move to the one lacuna, to the search for one crucial moment, seems to be soothing even in its affirmation that something will remain unknown. After all, the possibility Leiris has faced at the beginning of the chapter, namely that his entire psyche is to a large extent unknown to him and that his text, his self-construction as it were, is something foreign to him, is extremely troubling.
Sentence: Surely, looking for one central event that escapes him while saving the more general structure of the intelligibility of his text and the transparency of the self, is a much better choice.

Paragraph: Beyond defense, the answer to the question of why Leiris, whose writing so clearly fits the plural second model, still frames his writing excursions as a search for the one nub of essential meaning, is of course that the first model of the navel of the dream has a deep hold on him. There is a fundamental ambivalence in The Rules of the Game between the tendency in writing and thought to dispersion and the attraction exerted by the lacuna or the fantasmatic plenitude that finding a specific object or event can grant. For, defensive or not, the technique of branching associations is never free of the intense wish to find a focal point, a memory, an event that, when it is finally seized, will deliver the essence of life and an experience of the utter sense of being.
Context: Beyond defense, the answer to the question of why Leiris, whose writing so clearly fits the plural second model, still frames his writing excursions as a search for the one nub of essential meaning, is of course that the first model of the navel of the dream has a deep hold on him.
Sentence: There is a fundamental ambivalence in The Rules of the Game between the tendency in writing and thought to dispersion and the attraction exerted by the lacuna or the fantasmatic plenitude that finding a specific object or event can grant.

Paragraph: I feel I have drifted too long onto paths that fail to lead to the center, to the essential, and I wish to retrace my steps and come back to our central problem. Let me reconstruct how I have proceeded: Leiris has discovered a lacuna in his book. Following the discovery of the very fact that there are aspects of memory and the past that can completely evade self-exploration, Leiris has been swept up in a series of reflections on the multitude of events and small details that, while important to a life story, are not part of it since they have been forgotten or seen as unremarkable. He mentions the existence of various lacunae in his story and in memory, yet quickly converges to discussing one singular and particular lacuna. The most imperative lacuna for him, Leiris states, would be the precise moment when he discovered his mortality, a moment in time inaccessible to him, and he then moves into a groping search for such a moment.
Context: I feel I have drifted too long onto paths that fail to lead to the center, to the essential, and I wish to retrace my steps and come back to our central problem. Let me reconstruct how I have proceeded: Leiris has discovered a lacuna in his book. Following the discovery of the very fact that there are aspects of memory and the past that can completely evade self-exploration, Leiris has been swept up in a series of reflections on the multitude of events and small details that, while important to a life story, are not part of it since they have been forgotten or seen as unremarkable.
Sentence: He mentions the existence of various lacunae in his story and in memory, yet quickly converges to discussing one singular and particular lacuna.

Paragraph: Leiris places his quest for self-knowledge almost explicitly against that of psychoanalysis and finds his project lacking in comparison.11 It seems, however, that in this nearly direct reference to the Zuiderzee and Freud, Leiris’s aim is the reverse of what he claims. Here there is, to be sure, a statement of lack of success, both in general and with regard to the competitor—psychoanalysis. However, the claim of indolence and failure is only a part of the story. To see the whole story, the background reference to Freud has to be kept in mind: Leiris and Freud both compare the work of the completion of self-knowledge, the discovery of the unknown, and the unconscious within us to the definition of culture and art.
Context: Leiris places his quest for self-knowledge almost explicitly against that of psychoanalysis and finds his project lacking in comparison.11 It seems, however, that in this nearly direct reference to the Zuiderzee and Freud, Leiris’s aim is the reverse of what he claims. Here there is, to be sure, a statement of lack of success, both in general and with regard to the competitor—psychoanalysis.
Sentence: However, the claim of indolence and failure is only a part of the story.

Paragraph: Perhaps, Leiris seems to be saying in this passage, I am unable to fill the lacunae like the Zuiderzee, as psychoanalysis claims it can or should. I cannot substitute consciousness for unconsciousness, expanding the firm ground of knowledge at the expense of the depths of the unconscious, and thus uncover the hidden regions of myself. I cannot grasp the elusive truth. But filling the Zuiderzee is a metaphor for the art work itself, which organizes and settles what threatens us. Art does this, indeed, with the power of imagination and artificiality. I am an artist, and my writing, even though it is more construction and artificiality than reconstruction and truth, represents a great achievement. Perhaps I shall not be able to thoroughly understand, nor shall I succeed in recreating, but I will succeed, like a great artist, in mastering the unknown, and taming death. Yes, there will be a measure of invention, of creation instead of reconstruction, but therein lies my power.
Context: I cannot substitute consciousness for unconsciousness, expanding the firm ground of knowledge at the expense of the depths of the unconscious, and thus uncover the hidden regions of myself. I cannot grasp the elusive truth. But filling the Zuiderzee is a metaphor for the art work itself, which organizes and settles what threatens us.
Sentence: Art does this, indeed, with the power of imagination and artificiality.

Paragraph: These two difficulties, I wish to stress, are autobiographical ones: the fact that he will someday die poses a fundamental difficulty for Leiris’s writing about his own life, since something—something critical about him—will remain outside his own autobiography: the moment of his death. Hence, there is a fundamental failure in the autobiographical project: it cannot reach completion. The problem of death is a problem that concerns the future. Yet it is embodied in a difficulty of memory, one that concerns the past, an epistemological difficulty, as it were— namely the difficulty of reconstructing, in the retrospective autobiographical gaze upon his own life, the moment when Leiris knew that he was mortal.
Context: These two difficulties, I wish to stress, are autobiographical ones: the fact that he will someday die poses a fundamental difficulty for Leiris’s writing about his own life, since something—something critical about him—will remain outside his own autobiography: the moment of his death.
Sentence: Hence, there is a fundamental failure in the autobiographical project: it cannot reach completion.

Paragraph: The metaphor of the dream navel, then, creates and supports a certain structure of meaning and inquiry. Freud’s two models for what blocks self-knowledge are two models for approaching and seeking out psychic truth: A direct, vertical search for a buried core and a horizontal groping in all directions, gradually weaving a network of meaning.
Sentence: The metaphor of the dream navel, then, creates and supports a certain structure of meaning and inquiry.

Paragraph: Both Derrida and Weber then undermine the conception of the navel as one center loaded with meaning (even if absent) and point to the plurality and complexity of that center. Both possibilities, I maintain, are offered by Freud’s text. The navel is an inaccessible, privileged place of concise, particularly dense, meaning that hides the most important signification, and it is also a multivalent lattice that contains not too much meaning, but too little.
Sentence: Both Derrida and Weber then undermine the conception of the navel as one center loaded with meaning (even if absent) and point to the plurality and complexity of that center.

Paragraph: The search for one thing can be defensive or at least psychically preferable even if it presupposes failure (never finding). It is in a sense easier to think that somewhere inside is an inaccessible grain of meaning, than to acknowledge that everything is dispersed and cannot be consolidated. It seems less threatening to presuppose an image of a closed unitary wholeness where a founding element is missing, than to envision an image that disallows even in principle any form of closure, and that retains its irreducible plurality.
Sentence: The search for one thing can be defensive or at least psychically preferable even if it presupposes failure (never finding).

Paragraph: The two navels Freud describes are actually almost antithetical. Whereas the navel in the first citation is one unique point, a special psychic place or content, the second citation is about plurality: the analysis of the dream simply reaches a place where the branching out is too dense. Whereas in the first citation the navel—the area that remains inaccessible—is special, and consists of the heart or nucleus of meaning, in the second it is the complete opposite. There, the analysis of the dream advances and exposes various meanings, but in psychic life every item is related to other items, and so the items that the analysis leads to move further and further away from the dream itself until, at some point, the analysis ceases to be interesting: following the branches further away will not yield significant knowledge. That is, whereas in the first citation the navel is the most meaningful place, in the second it is the insignificant edges. Whereas in the first citation the navel is the hidden place hiding the secret, in the second the problem with the navel is that it is too exposed, consisting of overt, familiar contents with nothing secret about them. Whereas in the first citation the hidden area is isolated, in the second it is abundantly connected to the rest of psychic life.
Sentence: The two navels Freud describes are actually almost antithetical.

Paragraph: As for autobiography, the obstacles are also numerous. One of them, built into the very process of self-understanding, has to do with the reflexivity of the process, where the autobiographer is both the explorer and the object of exploration. This double aspect is the source of various inhibitions to clear vision, such as the tendency to look at the past through the lens of the present, or the fact that any writing about the past involves an unavoidable fictionalization. Other difficulties result from the inevitable complexities created by the passage through language, from the text’s relation to addressees, or from the structural difficulty of exploring our origins (or endings), summarized by Judith Butler: “There is that in me and of me for which I can give no account”.
Sentence: As for autobiography, the obstacles are also numerous.

Paragraph: Let’s return to Leiris. Both models in Freud are at work in Leiris’s text, and he seems to waver between them. Initially he goes with the second model. Having perceived the existence of the lacuna, the unconscious thread in his book, an “underground path,” Leiris embarks on an analysis of another aspect of his book’s unconscious.
Context: Let’s return to Leiris. Both models in Freud are at work in Leiris’s text, and he seems to waver between them.
Sentence: Initially he goes with the second model.

Paragraph: Indeed, after this passage, Leiris begins to tell a story (the memory of his first encounter with death, in the voice of the insect in Viroflay) with all the details, the tension and delays of a good story. Suddenly the art of storytelling returns to him. This is where the second volume finally begins, for until now we have only witnessed reflective contemplation on the ability or inability to make that beginning.
Sentence: Indeed, after this passage, Leiris begins to tell a story (the memory of his first encounter with death, in the voice of the insect in Viroflay) with all the details, the tension and delays of a good story.

Paragraph: Faced with the need to recognize a limit to analysis and knowledge, Freud then presents two models for the obstacle to self-knowledge. The first model is the secret, the one, the closed enigma, while the second is banality, plurality, lack of meaning, openness, and over-connectedness.
Sentence: Faced with the need to recognize a limit to analysis and knowledge, Freud then presents two models for the obstacle to self-knowledge.

Paragraph: It is as though Leiris creates this empty space, a blank square in his textualintellectual array. This vacuity seems seductive or defensive rather than real. It is an emptiness that is in fact fullness, a lacuna that promises to contain an intense grain of meaning, even when one does not know what that content is.
Sentence: It is as though Leiris creates this empty space, a blank square in his textualintellectual array.

Paragraph: Such an ideal, where it is held, is for both psychoanalysis and autobiography only one side of the coin. The other would be a structural impediment, an impediment- in-principle, in realizing this ideal. As far as psychoanalysis is concerned, some of its fundamental terms are names for a stubborn psychic element that withholds understanding (and change) in both analysand and analyst. The repetition compulsion is one name for this element. The drives themselves constitute a blind force immune to meaning. From another direction, processes of meaning formation in the psyche—the dream, the symptom, or the lapsus—are basically processes of distortion and confinement, through condensation, displacement, and other means, and so they render reconstruction or understanding difficult. The intra-psychic process that best embodies the difficulty on the path of the ideal of self-understanding is resistance. Resistance accompanies analysis all along, wearing creatively different faces, and is vital to it. Analysis is itself the gradual process of overcoming resistances to the work of analysis.
Context: The drives themselves constitute a blind force immune to meaning. From another direction, processes of meaning formation in the psyche—the dream, the symptom, or the lapsus—are basically processes of distortion and confinement, through condensation, displacement, and other means, and so they render reconstruction or understanding difficult. The intra-psychic process that best embodies the difficulty on the path of the ideal of self-understanding is resistance.
Sentence: Resistance accompanies analysis all along, wearing creatively different faces, and is vital to it.

Paragraph: This is a statement of failure, like so many others in Leiris’s works. Beyond the question of artificiality and reconstruction, Leiris understands that his quest for full self-understanding and clarification of his inner lacunae is limited. Was he so foolish, he seems to be asking, as to delude himself that he could fill the Zuiderzee, the vast and inaccessible empty void yawning inside?
Context: This is a statement of failure, like so many others in Leiris’s works. Beyond the question of artificiality and reconstruction, Leiris understands that his quest for full self-understanding and clarification of his inner lacunae is limited.
Sentence: Was he so foolish, he seems to be asking, as to delude himself that he could fill the Zuiderzee, the vast and inaccessible empty void yawning inside?

Paragraph: Perhaps, then, the secret lies in the infinite plurality of banal or unremarkable occurrences that form another kind of unconscious thread in his book. The model for a failure of knowing described by Leiris is very similar to Freud’s second model of the dream navel. It concerns a barrier to self-knowledge: unlike the more substantial or monumental events around which the narrative is woven, the less weighty ones are innumerable. Not only can Leiris not know them, even if he could, he would be unable to use them in telling a story that would capture some essence. The significant things would be blurred into an infinite array, and in an endless pursuit of details, self-knowledge would fail.
Context: Perhaps, then, the secret lies in the infinite plurality of banal or unremarkable occurrences that form another kind of unconscious thread in his book. The model for a failure of knowing described by Leiris is very similar to Freud’s second model of the dream navel.
Sentence: It concerns a barrier to self-knowledge: unlike the more substantial or monumental events around which the narrative is woven, the less weighty ones are innumerable.

Paragraph: In the attempt to fill the lacuna, Leiris examines, then, how death resonates within him. He conceives death, he writes, not as a decisive cut, a specific event, but as the feeling of standing on the edge of the abyss, on the threshold of another world .
Sentence: In the attempt to fill the lacuna, Leiris examines, then, how death resonates within him.

Paragraph: At this point, Leiris’s text moves from the realization that there are lacunae in one’s autobiography, in the attempt to know oneself, to the notion that what is most important is to understand and fill these lacunae. In other words, exploration should be geared towards precisely those things that are unattainable. He seems to be influenced here by the Freudian idea of parapraxis and Freudian thought in general. According to Freud, the place within discourse that is not easily given, the place that presents itself as void or forgotten, is precisely the place most abundant in meaning.
Context: At this point, Leiris’s text moves from the realization that there are lacunae in one’s autobiography, in the attempt to know oneself, to the notion that what is most important is to understand and fill these lacunae. In other words, exploration should be geared towards precisely those things that are unattainable. He seems to be influenced here by the Freudian idea of parapraxis and Freudian thought in general.
Sentence: According to Freud, the place within discourse that is not easily given, the place that presents itself as void or forgotten, is precisely the place most abundant in meaning.

Paragraph: Michel Leiris is considered the most innovative and influential figure in twentieth-century autobiography in the French language. His 1939 autobiography L’âge d’homme (Manhood), written a few years after a psychoanalytic treatment and in parallel to a second analysis, manifests strong psychoanalytic overtones . And yet Leiris tends to refer to psychoanalysis negatively throughout his life, perhaps because of a sense that psychoanalysis and autobiography are in conflict, being two parallel routes to self-understanding.
Context: Michel Leiris is considered the most innovative and influential figure in twentieth-century autobiography in the French language. His 1939 autobiography L’âge d’homme (Manhood), written a few years after a psychoanalytic treatment and in parallel to a second analysis, manifests strong psychoanalytic overtones .
Sentence: And yet Leiris tends to refer to psychoanalysis negatively throughout his life, perhaps because of a sense that psychoanalysis and autobiography are in conflict, being two parallel routes to self-understanding.

Paragraph: With this reservation, Leiris hints that while he is drawn to the first model of the dream navel and the nature of self-knowledge, he feels remote from it. He realizes that in a certain sense, the effort of reconstruction is illusory, and that he himself is incapable of being fully drawn into such an illusion. Doubt accompanies the entire description of the Viroflay episode, whose connection to the subject of death must constantly be reaffirmed. Significant here is not only the specific content of what Leiris says—the fear that the event never even happened—but the fact that he raises a doubt. This gap between the desire to find a unique moment and the practice of writing, that constantly, in parentheses, suggests alternative possibilities, finds divergent paths and raises doubts (“Perhaps I am distorting the quality of that noise … for it is doubtful that…”) is perhaps the predominant feature of Leiris’s texts.
Context: With this reservation, Leiris hints that while he is drawn to the first model of the dream navel and the nature of self-knowledge, he feels remote from it.
Sentence: He realizes that in a certain sense, the effort of reconstruction is illusory, and that he himself is incapable of being fully drawn into such an illusion.

Paragraph: The book as a whole is therefore meant to provide something of paramount importance to Leiris. Consequently, the fact that the book is incomplete—that the autobiography has holes, lacunae, and blind spots in it and that the project of self-understanding faces the possibility of a resounding failure—is significant. Once a hole has been discovered, it must be filled. The remainder of the chapter becomes an attempt at self-exploration focused solely on one specific issue.
Context: The book as a whole is therefore meant to provide something of paramount importance to Leiris. Consequently, the fact that the book is incomplete—that the autobiography has holes, lacunae, and blind spots in it and that the project of self-understanding faces the possibility of a resounding failure—is significant.
Sentence: Once a hole has been discovered, it must be filled.

Paragraph: There is often a passage in even the most thoroughly interpreted dream which has to be left obscure; this is because we become aware during the work of interpretation that at that point there is a tangle of dream-thoughts which cannot be unravelled and which moreover adds nothing to our knowledge of the content of the dream. This is the dream’s navel, the spot where it reaches down into the unknown. The dreamthoughts to which we are led by interpretation cannot, from the nature of things, have any definite endings; they are bound to branch out in every direction into the intricate network of our world of thought. It is at some point where this meshwork is particularly close that the dream-wish grows up, like a mushroom out of its mycelium.
Context: There is often a passage in even the most thoroughly interpreted dream which has to be left obscure; this is because we become aware during the work of interpretation that at that point there is a tangle of dream-thoughts which cannot be unravelled and which moreover adds nothing to our knowledge of the content of the dream. This is the dream’s navel, the spot where it reaches down into the unknown. The dreamthoughts to which we are led by interpretation cannot, from the nature of things, have any definite endings; they are bound to branch out in every direction into the intricate network of our world of thought.
Sentence: It is at some point where this meshwork is particularly close that the dream-wish grows up, like a mushroom out of its mycelium.

Paragraph: In spite of his enthusiastic lesson, Leiris seems unconvinced. The pendulum quickly swings back to the first model, with Leiris looking again for one, hidden event of cardinal importance, and whose meaning is concise and indispensable for the success of self-understanding. As Barberger shows (Leiris: L’écriture), yearning for the unique and lost object, the lacuna, the unattainable wholeness or the founding moment is central to Leiris’s oeuvre.
Context: In spite of his enthusiastic lesson, Leiris seems unconvinced.
Sentence: The pendulum quickly swings back to the first model, with Leiris looking again for one, hidden event of cardinal importance, and whose meaning is concise and indispensable for the success of self-understanding.

Paragraph: Weber opposes the mushroom mycelium, a sort of dense network, to the One (albeit missing) center that Lacan’s interpretation postulates. For Lacan, the navel is the hollow center, a gap, the place of the unconscious. But the difficulty with the navel, Weber claims, is not an absence of meaning but a surplus. Too much meaning can be what impedes dream interpretation, which proceeds by following chains of associative thought. These chains lead us on, and if we do what Freud wants us to and follow them, we might end up too far out and too far aside, losing the dream as we go. Seeing the dream as an unreachable center, Weber maintains, is a comforting alternative to allowing for the dense infinity of the dynamic and enclosing web.
Context: Weber opposes the mushroom mycelium, a sort of dense network, to the One (albeit missing) center that Lacan’s interpretation postulates. For Lacan, the navel is the hollow center, a gap, the place of the unconscious. But the difficulty with the navel, Weber claims, is not an absence of meaning but a surplus.
Sentence: Too much meaning can be what impedes dream interpretation, which proceeds by following chains of associative thought.

Paragraph: Most students responding to the survey indicated that they appreciated the SGL/A sessions and found them valuable as a method of review and preparation for the course summative examination.Many students offered suggestions for improvement. Below is a sam- ple of student comments and suggestions. They were selected to rep- resent both the strengths and weaknesses of the sessions
Context: Most students responding to the survey indicated that they appreciated the SGL/A sessions and found them valuable as a method of review and preparation for the course summative examination. Paragraph: Students were instructed to discuss and debate the question withintheir group and come to consensus regarding a best response to the question. After a reasonable amount of time, the instructor called upon the “group leader ”of each group to simultaneously raise a card representing the answer choice of that group. Cards were to be dis- played such that only the instructor could see the choice. The class as a whole was instructed to NOT look at answers chosen by othergroups and it is important that students adhere to this request. Paragraph: Consider writing your own question This recommendation may be difficult to achieve. The advantage of developing your own question pool is that questions can be appropri-ately linked to your specific course content, and of a depth and scope you expect of the students. Students invariably expect that whatever is embedded in a course, particularly what can be viewed as “practice questions ”, should contribute to success on the summative course examination. Questions that are not perceived to be tightly linked to course content may inadvertently distract some students leading to inefficient, inappropriate or ineffective study efforts. In addition, when content and knowledge is built progressively during the course,question difficulty and complexity can be fitted to the understanding students will be expected to demonstrate at specific intervals. This is an important consideration when multiple sessions are scheduledwithin a course. The challenge is in writing questions that are not so easy that all groups select the correct answer, but rather challenge students to question their understanding regarding a particular topic
Context: Consider writing your own question This recommendation may be difficult to achieve. The advantage of developing your own question pool is that questions can be appropri-ately linked to your specific course content, and of a depth and scope you expect of the students.

Our ses-sions, were initially developed to enhance class participation and engagement with the course material
