Paragraph: > Students can earn advanced placement credit for competence in a foreign language by taking the CEEB AP test or by taking the Cornell Advanced Standing Examination (CASE). Those with a score of 4 or 5 on the CEEB AP test in French, German, or Italian, will be awarded 3 credits. Qualification for the CASE (in any language) requires at least a 65 on a college placement test (taken either in high school or at Cornell during Orientation). Students achieving a passing score on the CASE will be awarded 3 credits. Language credits, earned via AP or CASE, may be used to satisfy part of the liberal studies distribution requirement (in the foreign language category) or the Advisor-approved elective requirement, contingent on discussion with the faculty advisor.  From https://www.engineering.cornell.edu/sites/default/files/departments/main%20area/pdf%20files/Fall-2017%20Cornell%20Engineering%20Handbook.pdf
Context: > Students can earn advanced placement credit for competence in a foreign language by taking the CEEB AP test or by taking the Cornell Advanced Standing Examination (CASE).
Sentence: Those with a score of 4 or 5 on the CEEB AP test in French, German, or Italian, will be awarded 3 credits.

Paragraph: It's huge and there's so much to do and learn. There are all kind of clubs and teams for every interest. There are top-notch programs in a wide variety of majors. And you'll meet people with a ridiculously broad range of interests. 10 years out, I have friends from Cornell who are engineers, doctors, vintners, chefs, mathematicians, teachers, programmers, school psychologists, sommeliers, bankers, veterinarians, scientists, entrepreneurs, activists, etc. I'm still in touch with some of my professors, and can feel their influence when I go to work (I'm a research engineer).  And don't forget, for all the complaints about the weather, summer in Ithaca is absolutely beautiful. If you do go, make sure to spend at least one summer in town - taking a class, working, doing research, or anything else that gives you an excuse to stay.
Context: There are all kind of clubs and teams for every interest. There are top-notch programs in a wide variety of majors. And you'll meet people with a ridiculously broad range of interests.
Sentence: 10 years out, I have friends from Cornell who are engineers, doctors, vintners, chefs, mathematicians, teachers, programmers, school psychologists, sommeliers, bankers, veterinarians, scientists, entrepreneurs, activists, etc.

Paragraph: I don't think they increase chances for veterans.  Grades are VERY low. Even if your school was CalTech, your grades are too low and it will reflect poorly if you can only get a 2.88 at the college you attended. If you want a chance, you should do CC and get high marks.
Sentence: I don't think they increase chances for veterans.

Paragraph: I was a non-CS major but got into programming during undergrad with a few courses.  INFO/CS 1300 is easy and will give you the skills to make basic websites, but there really isn't any programming involved (when I TA-ed there was maybe one small assignment that used javascript).  Even with no prior experience in programming, the 1300 --> 2300 --> 3300 sequence would be totally doable and would give you the skills to make interactive websites.  Definitely worthwhile and sounds like it would be a good bet for you.  You would have some projects that you could host online by the end of it all to show your skills too.  I can't speak to CS 1110 since I never took it, but a lot of people start there for getting into CS, and Python is always useful to know.  CS 2110 was a great course and really teaches you the fundamentals of CS.  But if you are only interested in front-end, then INFO/CS 1300, 2300 and 3300 would be a good track.  I would recommend CS 2110 to anybody though, since it opens up the option of taking some really cool courses later on like NLP!
Context: I can't speak to CS 1110 since I never took it, but a lot of people start there for getting into CS, and Python is always useful to know. CS 2110 was a great course and really teaches you the fundamentals of CS. But if you are only interested in front-end, then INFO/CS 1300, 2300 and 3300 would be a good track.
Sentence: I would recommend CS 2110 to anybody though, since it opens up the option of taking some really cool courses later on like NLP!

Paragraph: As someone with inside of knowledge of how the admissions process works for this, it is not a myth at all. There isn't really any way for me to prove this to you so we can agree to disagree here. You're certainly right that a Gov major would be more like what you'd be doing in Law School, but you're naive to think the smart people on the admissions boards at these institutions would equate a 4.0 in Chemical Engineering for example with one in Political Science. They're simply incomparable. Anyone with an ounce of intelligence knows this, and the people on these admissions committees aren't dumbos.   Edit: To elaborate a bit more, your research may corroborate what you think because that's exactly what admissions people want you to think. They want you to think it gives no advantage so that students don't think 'I should major in STEM even though I don't like it because it increases my chances' when this is the exact reality.
Context: As someone with inside of knowledge of how the admissions process works for this, it is not a myth at all.
Sentence: There isn't really any way for me to prove this to you so we can agree to disagree here.

Paragraph: I don't recommend Econ 3130. I went to one lecture and immediately dropped it. The lecture was impossibly boring and frankly I couldn't understand the professor's accent. I have heard that the tests are tough and rely on rote memorization. However I should add that I'm a stats major and not particularly interested in economics, so I switched to BTRY 3080 (Probability Models and Inference). Both classes cover highly theoretical statistics and the one I took used lots of multivariable calculus. I didn't take ILRST 2110 but it should be a good introduction to statistics beyond the basics you learned in high school. I believe the class uses R programming, so be prepared for that.
Context: I don't recommend Econ 3130. I went to one lecture and immediately dropped it.
Sentence: The lecture was impossibly boring and frankly I couldn't understand the professor's accent.
